10278.description: Score NYC is the local chapter servicing the NYC business community. We have over 90 members. Currently we are seeking a dynamic digital marketing professional, to lead our digital efforts. Volunteering at SCORE is one of the ways for you to give back to our community, stay connected with business leaders, and use your knowledge and expertise to bring SCORE’s resources to the next generation of entrepreneurs in your community. We hope to hear from you. RESPONSIBILITIES: Partner with the Marketing Chair in formulating a high impact, multi-channel marketing program Lead digital advertising initiative on Google Adwords and Facebook to increase workshop attendance, mentoring clientele, participation at major trade events, and volunteer signup Monitor, analyze and optimize ad performance and landing page effectiveness to maximize ROI Develop and lead a content marketing strategy; work with key constituents to create content and publish to our blog and other relevant platforms Manage our local chapter website and analyze web traffic to improve user experience and optimize for search and conversion Help create and lead an internal team of volunteers to execute and sustain this initiative VOLUNTEER REQUIREMENTS - 3+ years of experience creating, implementing, and tracking results of a targeted digital marketing program Fluency with Wordpress, Google Analytics, Hootsuite; Familiarity with SEOMoz, Leadpages, RiteTag, Semrush, etc.; Knowledge of HTML/CSS a plus Experienced in blogging, use of Google Adwords and paid ads on Facebook Attendance at marketing committee meetings, usually 2 hours each, once a month, at 26 Federal Plaza NYC, during business week Time commitment of 8-10 hours per week. Work is flexible and can be done virtually. TO APPLY - Email to: VOLUNTEERNOW@scorenyc.org ** your resume, a brief note regarding the number of hours you could volunteer each week AND please let us know the days and times you are NOT available. Any personal information you feel would help us get to know you better, including the circumstances that allow you to volunteer at this point in your life. Best day and time for you to come in to meet our team Your contact information ** Interviews for this position will be conducted by MARY TAN so please email both volunteernow@scorenyc.org and tan@scorenyc.org
10278.title: Volunteer - Digital Strategist

10278.description: Volunteer Opportunity for: Corporate Directors and Senior Management Consultants Position: Practice Leader, Advisory Board Practice to Small to Medium-size Enterprises in Manhattan, Brooklyn and The Bronx. Background: For over 50 years, SCORE Mentors have been providing counsel and assistance to thousands of entrepreneurs and small business owners across New York City. Some SCORE client firms have grown to the point that they need to add outside perspective and expertise to help them shape their business strategy and to keep them looking beyond managing their companies on a day to day basis to focus on the broader picture. SCORE NYC seeks to recruit an experienced corporate director or management consultant to create this practice. Responsibilities: With the ability to schedule this SCORE volunteer commitment around your available time, and working closely with SCORE NYC's senior leadership: Lead the effort to develop this Advisory Board practice; including identifying contacting, and persuading established businesses that they in fact would be well served by creating an Advisory Board Create ideal candidate profiles for members of the Advisory Board team; Build a roster of potential Advisory Board members from the current roster of SCORE Interview Mentors and qualified external recruits; Create practices and standards necessary to build a resource that will serve SCORE NYC's clients with distinction; Serve on one or multiple Advisory Boards in order to set a high level of service to SCORE's clients; Contribute to the strength and growth of SCORE New York through adding your management expertise to this totally volunteer organization. Ideal Candidate Profile: 30+ years as a business leader; Senior experience in general management, or on board(s) of directors, or in management consulting; An ability to quickly assess business opportunities and problems; Excellent listening skills and the ability to act as a responsible advisor; Ability to establish rapport with successful entrepreneurs and small business leaders. A real desire to help others succeed. Compensation: Volunteering at SCORE is one of the ways for you to give back to your community, connect with fellow business leaders, and pass on your knowledge and expertise to the next generation of entrepreneurs in your community. Enjoy the satisfaction of contributing to the success of others; Share great experience with other SCORE volunteers and make new friends; Provide leadership for the local business community; Participate in life-long learning, growing professionally and personally. To learn more about SCORE NYC, go to www.newyorkcity.scorenyc.org and If you’d like to discuss this opportunity to serve the New York business community: EMAIL: humanresources@scorenyc.org or CALL: Diane Drey, Score NYC Chapter Chair at 212-264-4507
10278.title: Volunteer - Advisory Board Member - for established businesses

10278.description: POSITION: Human Resources Manager for 100-person Volunteer Organization WORK SCHEDULE: Set your own hours; work from our headquarters in lower Manhattan or from home. THE ORGANIZATION: SCORE, is a national business mentoring organization with 300+ offices and 11,000+ volunteers. It's mission is to provide FREE one-on-one confidential business counseling and affordable, skills-based workshops to small business owners and those wishing to start a business. SCORE NYC has five convenient offices located in Brooklyn, Bronx and Manhattan. Annually, it assists over 5,000 clients and conducts in excess of 8,000 client mentoring sessions THE CHALLENGE: We are continually looking for new members who are at at or near to retirement. We seek a Human Resource professional who can help us grow our volunteer resources through proactive recruitment efforts. The professional will create and execute a plan to recruit business executives and senior managers and professionals as our front-line volunteer mentors. THE OPPORTUNITY: To have a major impact on the growth of SCORE NYC and be the senior HR right hand to its Chairperson. COMPENSATION: This is a volunteer position. But the psychic rewards can be great: ■ Enjoy the satisfaction of being a key driver of the growth of an important contributor to NYC’s business health; ■ Share great experience with other SCORE volunteers and make new friends; ■ Provide leadership for the local business community; ■ Participate in lifelong learning, growing professionally and personally. RESPONSIBILITIES: With the ability to schedule your SCORE commitment to your personal convenience: ■ Work with the Chair to establish the specifics of a recruitment plan; ■ Work with senior SCORE Mentors to leverage their contacts as recruitment tools; ■ Establish relationships with other senior HR executives to spread the word of SCORE’s need; ■ Devise and execute the optimum use of social media to achieve our recruitment goals; ■ Devise strategies to enlist the aid of executive recruiters and outplacement firms to achieve our recruitment goals; ■ Contribute to the strength and growth of SCORE New York through adding your management expertise to this totally volunteer organization. IDEAL CANDIDATE PROFILE: • 5+ years experience working in the Human Resource field; • Availability to volunteer for 10+ hours per month • Willingness to participate in an orientation program (approx 40 hours - can be spread out over multiple weeks) • Desire to give back to the business community and work with other professional volunteers
10278.title: Human Resources & Recruitment Opportunity

10035.description: Reading Partners is currently recruiting volunteers for fall 2017! Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning. The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10035.title: Become a reading partner this fall- make a lifelong impact on a child (NYC)

10128.description: Learning Through Art Volunteer Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is seeking volunteers to support teaching artists in New York City public school classrooms where the Learning Through Art (LTA) program is implemented. LTA Volunteers should be enthusiastic about arts education/integration and able to make a commitment to assist a teaching artist one day each week for the duration of the 20-week residency. LTA places teaching artists in New York City public school classrooms, where they collaborate with teachers to create process-oriented art projects that examine ideas and themes related to the school curriculum. In these 20-week residencies, teaching artists introduce art techniques and concepts and encourage students to view, analyze, and discuss works of art. Founded in 1937, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation is dedicated to promoting the understanding and appreciation of art, architecture, and other manifestations of visual culture, primarily of the modern and contemporary periods. The Guggenheim realizes this mission through exceptional exhibitions, education programs, research initiatives, and publications. The Guggenheim strives to engage and educate an increasingly diverse international audience through its unique network of museums and partnerships. With nearly three million annual visitors worldwide, the Guggenheim and its network is one of the most visited cultural institutions in the world. Responsibilities of a LTA Volunteer include: Distribute all art materials to students as directed by teaching artist. Help to maintain an organized classroom throughout each session and manage clean-up and storage of materials. Photograph (when advised by teaching artist) students at work in the classroom. Photograph one individual work for each student in February/March to be included in the catalog and exhibition slide show. Assisting the teaching artist in hanging in-school exhibitions and other displays of student artwork throughout the year As advised by teaching artist, work with students one-on-one and in small groups as needed. Helping with LTA events as needed, including family days at the Guggenheim Museum This is a volunteer position. Volunteers receive invitations to Guggenheim programs, free admission to museums across the country, discounts at the Guggenheim restaurants and store and the opportunity to learn about art education, museum education and modern and contemporary art. If you have any questions, please feel free to email learningthroughart@guggenheim.org. Volunteer commitment is once weekly from approximately mid-October through early May. TO APPLY: Please complete the LTA volunteer application found at www.guggenheim.org/lta. Email with a cover letter and résumé to learningthroughart@guggenheim.org or mail to Learning Through Art, 1071 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10128.

10029.description: The Carter Burden Network is dedicated to supporting the efforts of older people to remain in their homes living independently, safely, and with dignity. Volunteers are an integral component of the Carter Burden Network's 40+ years of success. No matter your age, experience or schedule, CBN can accommodate your needs to ensure that you have a meaningful and effective volunteer experience. The Friendly Visiting program matches volunteers with seniors who share common interests and hobbies for social interaction. Volunteers participate in visits at least twice a month (for 1-2 hours) in a senior's home and may chat, play a game, read a book, take a walk (if the senior is able), or another activity. The Friendly Visiting program is an on-going opportunity. We are looking for compassionate, patient, and committed volunteers comfortable engaging with seniors having memory issues. Time is flexible but we are looking for volunteers available on weekdays (in the afternoons) or weekends. If you are interested in this opportunity please email us at: volunteer@carterburdennetwork.org
10029.title: Become a friendly visitor!

10029.description: Friendly Visiting is a program that pairs volunteers with homebound seniors to provide company and friendship. We ask volunteers to commit to visit their senior match one time per week for a period of six months or more. We are seeking volunteers to visit seniors who live between 96th and 145th street on the east side of Manhattan. If you are interested in learning more about this opportunity, please reply with your phone number and the best time to reach you. Thank you!
10029.title: Friendly Visiting- East Harlem

10029.description: URGENT! We need Classroom Aide Volunteers for our Early Childhood Socialization groups, starting September 18th. Volunteer aides help support the mom/toddler interaction in a cheerful, interactive classroom setting. We have approximately 10 - 15 moms/toddlers (15 months - 3 years of age) per class. Focus of the program is supporting the development and socialization needs of the child, and support the bonding between parent and child, so that the child can achieve the milestones for development. Includes art and music activities as well as free play in the classroom to support the learning needs of the child and fosters bonding between parent and child. Hours needed: 2 sessions a day available between Monday and Thursdays. Ideally a volunteer will commit to two days a week: Mondays and Wednesdays, 9:30 - 11:30 and 12:30 - 2:30 or Tuesdays and Thursdays from 9:30 - 11:30 and 12:30 - 2:30 pm. 10029.title: URGENT! We need Classrooms Aides for our Early Childhood Socialization Program

10029.description: East Harlem Tutorial Program offers a variety of volunteer opportunities through our charter schools and after-school programs, ranging from subject-matter tutoring, providing students with homework help, mentoring, and preparing high school students for college success. Volunteers work with our scholars, preparing them for academic success, supporting their social enrichment, and helping them gain the confidence they will need to succeed in college and in life. Check out our volunteer options below: Find more info here: https://ehtp.org/volunteer Apply here: http://bttr.im/ubhw2 Volunteer Opportunities Classroom Buddies - Volunteers work in one of our Kindergarten through 5th Grade after-school classes assisting our scholars with homework, walking them through engaging classroom activities, and supporting our Assistant and Lead Teachers. Commitment: At least twice a week When: Monday through Thursday, 4pm - 6pm Elementary Homework Help - Volunteers support our young scholars as they tackle tough homework while building supportive relationships and positively impacting their academic achievement. In small groups, volunteers address the individual needs of our scholars and focus on content they are learning during the week. Commitment: Once a week When: Saturdays, 10am - 11:30am Scholars Friday Clubs -Volunteers engage in fun clubs geared toward getting our scholars active and expressing themselves creatively! Volunteers can choose clubs such as dance club, theater/drama club, music/percussion, capoeira (Brazilian martial arts), and soccer. No experience needed -- just a can do attitude! Commitment: Once a week When: Fridays, 1pm - 4pm Road to Success - Middle School is some of the most formative years for East Harlem’s young people. These years will determine which high school they get into and ultimately whether they go to college. Road to Success provides a small group setting where scholars receive homework help from volunteers interested in making a difference in the lives of young people. Commitment: At least once a week When: Monday through Thursday, 5pm - 6pm University Tutoring - Volunteers help our middle and high school scholars succeed in various subjects (Math, English, Science, History), while in a one-on-one setting. Volunteers should feel confident tutoring and demonstrate success in a 6th - 12th grade level subject. Commitment: Once a week When: Monday and Wednesday, 6:30pm - 8pm College Mentoring Program - The College Mentoring Program is a one-on-one mentoring project that aims to guide high school students through the entire college application process. The program’s goal is to ensure that each senior successfully applies to college, finds financial aid, and chooses the school that is best suited for their needs. The Program is a two year commitment for both the mentor and mentee, with weekly requirements in the first year and monthly requirements in the second year. Commitment: Once a week When: Tuesday and Wednesday, 6:30pm - 8pm
10029.title: Do you love working with young people? Volunteer at East Harlem Tutorial Program!

10029.description: We have an urgent need for after school Home Work Help volunteers to assist school aged East Harlem children in our after school Home Work Help program. You can volunteer on either Tuesdays from 4:30 - 6 pm or Thursdays from 4:30 - 6 pm. We have a group of 25 children who receive tutoring twice a week and who come twice a week with their homework. You might assist one child during the entire session or additional children as may be needed. You can do one or both sessions a week. Please contact the Volunteer Director at tgough@lsafhs.org Thank you for your consideration!
10029.title: URGENT!  Home Work Help Volunteers Needed!

10029.description: As we are currently facing very difficult budget cuts in New York State, our Food Pantry which serves East Harlem children and families is experiencing a dramatic reduction of donations. Our shelves are barely stocked. If you work for an organization that might be interested in hosting a Food Drive, please be in touch (646) 672-0434. 10029.description: STARTING IN OCTOBER 2017: Help us help the neediest students in New York City! ! We need caring, committed after school Tutors for our After School Tutoring Program for children in K - 3. Times needed: MONDAYS AND WEDNESDAYS FROM 3:30 - 4:30. Tutors ideally commit to two days a week as you would tutor the same child twice a week. You will tutor one-on-one a child in grades K- 3 who struggles with reading and writing at grade level. Most of the children are children of immigrants and English is not spoken at home, so they struggle with English reading and writing at school. Tutoring begins mid October and continues through the spring sememster (until June 2018). Please help an East Harlem child! Tutoring makes all the difference for our children -- the difference between success and failure in school. If you would like to volunteer, please email an inquiry email with your resume to tgough@lsafhs.org
10029.title: URGENT!!  We Need Tutors to Tutor East Harlem Children Mondays and Wednesdays!

10029.description: The Ambassador Volunteer Program welcomes patients, families and visitors as they enter the Hospital and escorts them to their destination. The hours are Monday -Friday from 8AM - 5:00 PM. Mount Sinai is large and there are 12 buildings most of which are connected by a main corridor (underground) level. The Ambassadors help patients, families, and visitors figure out where they have to go (through Ipad technology and skills we teach them) and then escort them there. We ask Ambassadors to serve at least one 3-4 hour session per week. We have an orientation and then pair new Ambassadors up with an experienced Ambassador. It is an excellent opportunity to improve your communication skills, learn what it is like to be part of a large healthcare organization, find out how gratifying it is to help others, and become a more active person. If you are kind, compassionate, willing to walk throughout the Hospital, and like to help people we can teach you to be an Ambassador!
10029.title: Mount Sinai Volunteer Ambassador

10029.description: Do you work for a company that wants to assist underpriviliged children in New York City? Help us give healthy sancks to children in our Summer Reading and Math Academy: https://yougivegoods.com/lsa-healthysnackdrive Othere ways your company can help: 1) Your company can host a Toy or Book Drive for children in our programs. We are always in need for educational toys and books for children ages 0 - 12. (we can pick up donations as needed). Our Holiday Program for Families is always in need of new clothing/toys/books for children, especially as gifts for the holidays. 2) Your company can host a Party for children at your office - a great \"team building\" activity for your company and a great way for our children to enjoy an outing and interaction with caring adults. Activities typically include an activity, i.e. art or craft making, and treats (food/snacks). 10029.description: We need an Advocate for our Advocacy/Emergency Services program. Position requires a commitment for at least two full days, between Monday thru Friday 9 am - 5 pm. Advocate meets one-one one with clients by appointment, conducting intakes, assessing the client's needs, distributing food from the food pantry, and making referrals for necessary services. Duties also includes preparing food packages and stocking and maintaining the food pantry; educating clients regarding government benefits and entitlements; representing clients and advocating on their behalf at the city welfare center or at state hearings; making referrals for child care, counseling, legal assistance, job training, etc. Assist clients to identify and address underlying problems that bring families to the Adovcacy office. 10026.description: Come enliven the spirits of students between the ages of 4 and 12 in our Saturday TechFests! In our TechFests, we introduce to students a STEM topic: Coding an App, Engineering a Circuit, Maker Space topic, or a Science concept. We then teach them the basics of this topic, and then they practice it before making an actual product using the concepts they learned. Your job is to support the instructor (unless you step up to be the instructor, and this has happened on occasion) and to support the students in using the concepts they may be learning for the first time to build a product. You may not be well versed in the STEM concept, but not to worry - there will be some training and orientation beforehand, and we have found that usually it's being there to support the student, along with your own critical thinking and reasoning, you both will be able to figure it out together. We do not introduce extremely complicated STEM concepts (such as Raspberry Pi, Arduino, Java) unless we will have a number of those masters in the room. The STEM concepts we teach are applicable for early learners of STEM, where the barriers to accessing the content is low. We do offer challenging concepts, but they are taught in ways that will reduce stress and frustration, as it's our aim to have the students walking away from the session feeling great about their accomplishments, as well as having learned something new. We also want YOU to have a great experience! The TechFests on the 1st and 2nd Saturdays will be on the campus of Columbia University. These students will be ages 8-12. The time will be 8:30-12:30. The 3rd Saturday TechFest will be at JCC Harlem. These students will be ages 4-8. The time will be 12:45-3:45.

HEAF is seeking dedicated and passionate individuals to serve as academic coaches to provide tutoring and support to our College Quest (High School) students, grades 9-11. Our students need your help in the following subject areas High School: English, History (Global, U.S), Math (Trigonometry, Geometry, Algebra), Physics, Biology, Chemistry, Earth Science, Spanish, French Time Commitment: 2hrs/Week Middle School: English Language Arts (ELA), Math (ratios, percentages, decimals, single variable equations, solving for X, plotting points on a graph) and Social Studies Time Commitment: 1/Hr a week, Saturdays About HEAF: The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. (HEAF) is a comprehensive not-for-profit supplemental education and youth development organization that supports and assists dedicated students to develop the intellectual curiosity, academic ability, social values and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career and life. Coaches are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Ability to work collaboratively with the HEAF staff Ability and willingness to commit to academic year Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply. *This position is unpaid

10027.description: DESCRIPTION Start Small Think Big (Start Small) is a not-for-profit organization located in Harlem. Our mission is to help low- to moderate-income individuals build and sustain thriving businesses in order to increase their personal financial security and stimulate economic activity in underserved communities in New York City and the Bay Area. We believe that entrepreneurship results in increased innovation and sustained economic growth for everyone, in particular, those most traditionally marginalized. The Marketing and Event Coordination Internship will work with the Market Access Program Director in assisting small business entrepreneurs in identifying and exploring new and varied sales opportunities for their business. The position will play a key role in helping Start Small Think Big develop community partnerships and formalizing a marketing strategy for sales opportunities, this includes but is not limited to, learning more about the various local sales opportunities available in NYC and the Bay Area and managing the communication and marketing of these opportunities to our community of entrepreneurs. Job Responsibilities shall include, but are not limited to: Manage weekly \"Tasting Thursdays\" at our office, which includes identifying new participants for sales opportunity, coordinating logistics with entrepreneurs prior to and during their scheduled tasting, and recording sales data after each opportunity. Write, produce, and help manage content to feature on SSTB Sales Alert emails, which feature key free, discounted, and paid opportunities available in their communities. Research and develop a database of all seasonal and year-round opportunities available in NYC and Bay Area. Develop resource guide on topics of interest for our entrepreneurs, as it relates to their marketing challenges, including but not limited to, web design resources, how to optimize sales, and strategies for successful social media use. Collaborate with Program Director to contact each retail opportunity to see whether a partnership is possible and if our entrepreneurs could tap into free and discounted vendor space. Coordinate all logistics related to featuring Start Small Businesses in retail opportunities with local street markets, fairs, and stores. Preferred Skills/Qualifications: Current undergraduate student with strong interest in writing, social media, and communications, nonprofit program management, or other related disciplines. High level of computer proficiency including familiarity with Google Applications, social media (Facebook and Instagram) and MS Office. Demonstrated commitment to inclusive community/economic development, social and economic justice work, and/or anti-poverty work; Excellent verbal and written communication skills, time management, and interpersonal skills; Highly organized, detail-oriented, creative and self-motivated; a strong problem-solver and critical thinker; and Experience working in low-income and/or immigrant communities. Start Small Think Big is an equal opportunity employer with a standing policy of nondiscrimination. This means that all qualified persons are accorded an equal opportunity for employment or promotion without regard to actual or perceived race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, disability, medical condition, marital status, sex, age, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, family responsibility, personal appearance, genetic information, matriculation, or political affiliation. HOW TO APPLY mabell@startsmallthinkbig.org Submit resume or LinkedIn profile to: Mabell Fernandez, Market Access Program Director at mabell@startsmallthinkbig.org (include subject line: \"[your name] Marketing and Event Coordination Internship\"

10027.description: Located in Harlem on 132nd Street, Cecil Ivory House is a 24 bed transitional housing program targeting formerly homeless clients who are either mentally ill or dually diagnosed as mentally ill and chemically addicted. The mission of this program is to provide a safe and supportive environment where residents take part in rehabilitation interventions that will assist them in the attainment of their work, social and community living goals. A variety of services are available, including case management, substance abuse groups, medication monitoring, daily skills training and recreational activities. Now is your chance to step up and help us in our goals! Do you enjoy socializing, running game nights, showing movies or turning the stereo up a bit for a little dancing? Are you able to introduce yourself, share a few jokes, spread some smiles and host a small party? If so, the residents of Cecil Ivory would love to have you host a small Friday Night Social. We’ll provide the games, snacks and music; you just need to bring the smiles and good times! We are looking to start this up at 6:30pm and make it a bi-weekly event. So put on your party shirt and give me a call! PLEASE NOTE: In order to insure the integrity of the BRC volunteer program, as well as the well being of the clients we service, all interested parties must complete a New Volunteer Registration form and attend an orientation, prior to receiving an assignment. Apologies, but we are unable to accept walk-ins.

Then join us at least once, or frequent our STEM Kids NYC Science Cafe that will open every Thursday and Friday throughout the school year. In this cafe, you'll have the opportunity to work with our Science teacher and to share your love for Science and engage with our students in hands-on activities that supports what you do for a living, or some other area in Science you have a penchant for. Don't worry about teaching! You'll receive all the support you need from us who will develop the lessson plan around your expertise, and be there with you to help facilitate the sessions. Your presence and contribution of mastery is invaluable in helping students tap into their natural ability for Science, as well as enable them to develop their own identify around being a Scientist themselves. Your time commitment would be for a 3 hour segment for one or multiple Fridays. It's your choice. Thank you in advance for your consideration!
10027.title: Calling All Scientists! Join Our Student Science Cafe!

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a part-time 14-hours per week, unpaid telecommuting internship. The internship is 4-months and responsible for leading public and political outreach in the state and district assigned to. Key Responsibilities: - Must be available Mondays 4:30-6:00 PM PST for The Borgen Project’s national conference call. - Meet with members of Congress and/or Congressional staffers in your State and District. - Represent The Borgen Project at various business, political and community events. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Mobilize individuals to contact their members of Congress in support of key poverty-reduction legislation. - As needed, speak to groups, classes and organizations. - Write letters of support for key programs to political leaders, media and other groups. Qualifications: - Outstanding writing skills. - Self-starter who can produce great results with limited supervision. - Strong oral communication skills and ability to lead meetings and give speeches.
10027.title: Political Affairs Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a 12-week, part-time, unpaid internship. The selected candidate will be able to work from home and set their own schedule, but must meet weekly deadlines. Articles submitted will appear on BORGEN Magazine or The Borgen Project Blog. Key Responsibilities: - Interview sources and research topics in-depth. - Write one well-researched article per week. - Communicate with editors and supervisors. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Attend national conference call and/or training every Monday at 4 - 5:30 PM PST. Qualifications: Strong journalism writing skills. Must be able to work independently and meet deadlines with very little supervision. Experience writing for newspapers is helpful, but not required.
10027.title: Journalism Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a 12-week, part-time, unpaid internship. The selected candidate will be able to work from home and pick their own schedule, but must meet weekly deadlines. Articles submitted will appear on BORGEN Magazine or The Borgen Project Blog. Key Responsibilities: - Write one article per week. - Research topics. - Assist with advocacy efforts. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Attend national conference call and/or training every Monday at 4 - 5:30 PM PST. Qualifications: Strong research and writing skills. Must be able to work independently and meet deadlines with very little supervision. Experience writing SEO friendly content is helpful, but not required.
10027.title: Writer Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. The Borgen Project is hiring an HR Intern who will work remotely. This human resources role will focus on national recruitment and updating job postings. Key Responsibilities: - Update job postings (80% of internship). - Inform groups and classes of openings. - Take on various tasks as needed. - Everyone who is part of the organization assists the team with fundraising, 25-hours of this position is dedicated to creating and implementing a personal fundraising campaign. - Assist with advocacy efforts. Details: This is an unpaid internship, although college credit is available. The HR internship is 12-hours per week for 12-weeks.
10027.title: HR Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. The Borgen Project is hiring a Public Relations/Marketing Intern who will work remotely. This public relations intern will be involved in a variety of aspects of marketing and communications. Key Responsibilities: - Create a branding campaign. - Conduct an informal focus group and gather feedback for market research. - Pitch story ideas to print, broadcast and digital media. - Create and implement a fundraising strategy. - Plan, market and present at an informational meeting. - Utilize social media and develop strategies for web-based messaging. - Assist with The Borgen Project's advocacy efforts. - Take on assignments as needed. Details: This is an unpaid internship, although college credit is available. The internship is 12-hours per week for 12-weeks. Must meet weekly deadlines.
10027.title: Public Relations/Marketing Internship

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. You don’t need to be a lobbyist to help influence foreign policy. As a Regional Director, you’ll serve as a Borgen Project Ambassador in your city - mobilizing your friends, family and colleagues to contact Congress in support of key poverty reduction legislation. This is an unpaid, volunteer position. Key Responsibilities: - Attend one (30-60 minute) national conference call per month: 5PM PDT 6PM MDT 7PM CDT 8PM EDT - Meet with local congressional leaders and lobby for legislation that improves living conditions for the world’s poor. - Mobilize people in your community to contact their congressional leaders to support poverty reduction legislation. - Manage and implement fundraising campaigns. - Build a network of people engaged in the cause. - Serve as The Borgen Project’s ambassador in your city. Qualifications: - Basic understanding of U.S. Politics and international development. - Highly organized with the ability to prioritize multiple functions and tasks while managing their work time efficiently. - Strong team player that loves to bring new ideas to the table. - Ability to demonstrate frequent independent judgment with decisiveness. - Excellent overall communication skills: oral, written, presentation.
10027.title: Regional Director

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis. This is a great entry-level volunteer position for someone looking to be part of The Borgen Project. Advocates can operate from anywhere in the U.S. This is an unpaid, volunteer position. Key Responsibilities: - Attend one (30-60 minute) national conference call per month: 5PM PDT 6PM MDT 7PM CDT 8PM EDT - Serve as an ambassador for the world’s poor. Build awareness of the issues and ways people can help. - Manage and implement fundraising campaigns. - Represent The Borgen Project in your city - attend events and engage people in the cause. - Contact congressional leaders in support of key poverty-reduction programs. Qualifications: - Excellent overall communication skills: oral, written, presentation. - Ability to self-manage and prioritize assignments.
10027.title: Advocate

10027.description: Lead three day, life changing experiential workshops in New York State prisons, schools and communities through exercises in affirmation, communication, cooperation, community building and creative conflict transformation. AVP is based on the understanding that every person is valuable and that wisdom lies within the group. Facilitators do not have answers. We are all learning together. Facilitators create a safe place for participants to discover our own truths. Key responsibilities: Facilitate on-team three day workshops Monitor group process and respond to keep building community and provide exercises and material at an engaging level Work collaboratively with a team to plan and lead a meaningful and dynamic workshop Report on the work done to AVP New York
10027.title: Alternatives to Violence Project Workshop Facilitator

10027.description: We're looking for CodeSters who have the ability, fluidity, and patience to work with students between grades 1-8 with instruction on app development, website development, robotics, or game development. The use of Coding Blocks is the chosen way to do this. You will be on the cutting edge of teaching computer science concepts, as less than 10% of New York City, as well as US schools have a computer science curriculum. You will utilize the existing creativity that already exists within the spirits of children, as well as their knack for apps and video games, and channel this energy into supporting them in learning wireframing, weibsite, app & game development. If you are into Scratch, Arduino, JavaScript or HTML, this is a PLUS, as we would love to introduce an actual computer programming language to students, after they have mastered programming logic. Come contribute your mastery to increase the interest in STEM in our students in one of our Harlem locations!
10027.title: Teach Kids How To Code

10027.description: We're looking for instructors who have the ability, fluidity, and patience to work with students in grades 1-8 with instruction on Science, Engineering, app development, website development, robotics, or game development. You will be on the cutting edge of teaching computer science concepts, as less than 10% of New York City and Northern New Jersey public schools has a computer science curriculum! What's more, 10% of US schools have a computer science curriculum. You will utilize the existing creativity that already exists within the spirits of children, as well as their knack for apps and video games, and channel this energy into supporting them in learning wireframing, weibsite, app & game development. We operate within an afterschool model, in that schools and community based organizations utilize our expertise to provide quality programming to their students and program participants. Your schedule and availability will be matched with the school or community-based afterschool program. If you are into Scratch, Arduino, JavaScript, or HTML, this is a PLUS. We generally utilize coding blocks in our coding classes, but we are always interested in introducing computer programming languages. If you are into Physics, Virtual Reality, Augmented Reality, Arduino programming, or building computers, we definitely want to speak with you! Come contribute your mastery to increase the interest in STEM with our students in Harlem!
10027.title: STEM and STEAM Enthusiasts Needed Afterschool!

10027.description: Urban Church Intern: Mt. Pleasant Church City Vision Internships is a Christian one-year, multi-year or summer internship program based on the AmeriCorps model. Interns serve at one of over 40 positions across the USA and Canada. In the past 10 years, we have placed over 500 full-time interns and 68,000 volunteers in hundreds of Christian ministries. Description: We seek to provide opportunities that will cause growth and prepare the interns for the commitment that the work world requires. Listed below are some of the possibilities that the intern may have to choose from: -Teaching Children and teenagers during the Sunday Church School, ages 4-18. -Learning the curriculum of our Christian school and assisting in our learning center during the school day. -Working in the after school program with neighborhood students who have learning challenges. -Assisting in the morning worship experience by reading scripture, prayers, leading the congregation in worship songs, or sharing a spiritual thought. -Working with the girls in the residential program as they get their homework done, prepare meals, and supervise the bed time process. Benefits: For Interns without a Bachelors Degree: One Year Work Study Internship -Provides a work study internship with free tuition in City Vision College for a full year paid by hosting ministry. -Online courses providing accredited degrees in Nonprofit Management, Addiction Studies, and Urban Missions. -Any Pell grant or other federal financial aid paid as cash payment to student (up to $5,645). -Expectation is typically 29 hours of volunteer work with 16 hours of class work per week (45 hours total). For Interns with a Bachelors Degree: One Year Paid Internship, Multi-Year Graduate Fellowship or Technology Ministry Master's Fellowship One Year Paid Internship -Volunteer Interns paid a living stipend from $200-$600/month (depending on site). -Free tuition in City Vision College for a full year paid by hosting ministry. (Optional) -Expectation is typically 40 hours of volunteer work per week. Multi-Year Graduate Fellowship -Free tuition in Bakke Graduate University programs including MBA, Masters in Global Leadership or Social Entrenpreneurship or Doctorate in Ministry or Transformational Leadership -Some sites may provide an additional stipend for outstanding candidates. -Candidates may receive up to 6 hours of independent study credit based on practicum work at ministry site. -Supervised nonprofit or ministry experience interning 29 hours per week. Requirements -At least 18 years old and have a high school diploma or equivalent (GED) -Must be a Christian -U.S. citizen, U.S. national or lawful permanent resident alien, or have a valid student or work visa -Able to make at least a summer, six month or one year commitment (may be extended by mutual agreement) depending on internship type -Able to financially live on just free housing (if offered) and any outside income sources you have. -Able to relocate (unless there is a site near you) For more information or to apply visit cityvisioninternships.org.
10027.title: Urban Ministry Internship: Mt. Pleasant Church in Harlem, NY

10024.description: Volunteers at Star tutor students from low-income families who need help with reading, writing, math or other subjects. The students range in age from 2nd to 12th grade, and attend public and parochial schools across the city. About 65% of students come from families where Spanish is the primary language spoken at home. Tutors complete a written application form and interview, and are matched with an appropriate student. Once the tutor is matched, he/she receives an orientation, and then works one-to-one with the same student each week for two hours. The Center is open for tutoring on Mondays and Wednesdays from 3 to 7 pm, and on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays from 3:30 to 6 pm. You do not need to speak Spanish for this position. ***WE CURRENTLY HAVE A NUMBER OF HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WHO STILL DO NOT HAVE TUTORS! These students need primary help in Math and Science classes. The ability to help with other subjects, such as writing, would be helpful. You can apply now by visiting https://www.goddard.org/grcc/volunteer/starlearning/ and completing the Tutor Application: School Year.
10024.title: Math and Science Tutors Needed for HS Students!

10024.description: Intergenerational Chess at DOROT Share your love of the game and bring a smile to a senior. \"One of the best things about playing chess with Mr. B is how excited we are to see each other.\" -Zach, age 13 Registration is still open on a rolling basis! Fall/Winter: Jan. 08 - May. 14 from 4:00-5:30pm Students and DOROT Seniors will get to know each other and play chess together. Refreshments will be served. Free. Requirements: for 6th - 12th grade students must commit to all sessions understand the game of chess understand the different chess pieces and how to move them Intergenerational Chess at DOROT is sponsored by the Targoff family and friends
10024.title: Intergenerational Chess - Youth Needed to Play Chess with Seniors

10024.description: A special intergenerational reading adventure for 3rd and 4th graders. We are still accepting students on a rolling basis! Students spend time reading and discussing books with older adults. The program is ideal for youth to gain encouragement to reach for a book and spend time discussing books. students will nurture their natural love of reading and engage in a variety of fun and creative intergenerational activities. The group will read aloud a few books over the course of 14 sessions and discuss the major themes of the books respecting other’s differences and the value of kindness. Great food and art activities will follow. 2017 Dates: September 13 (orientation for youth,) September 27 October 4, 18, 25 November 1, 8, 15, 29 December 6, 13, 20 Jan 3, 10, 17 3rd and 4th graders can register online at: http://www.dorotusa.org/book. Only 12 spaces are available for youth. Parents need a pre-phone interview. For more information, please contact Shai Rosenfeld at srosenfeld@dorotusa.org or 917-441-5051
10024.title: Reading Adventure for 3rd and 4th Grade Students

10024.description: Ms. P is a lovely senior living on the upper west side with her husband. Ms. P is a retired actor and costume designer on Broadway. Ms. P would love a friendly visitor to converse with and liven up her week. She is a very pleasant person and is sure to put a smile on your face. Ms. P has Alzheimer’s, and it limits her conversational abilities. We are looking for volunteers who have experience with Alzheimer’s disease (in a professional or personal capacity). This opportunity is part of Encore Community Service's Friendly Visiting Program. We ask for a commitment of 6 months, during which time visits take place every week. There is a short interview and orientation process, as well as a background check.
10024.title: Visit with the charming Ms. P., Retired Actor and Costume Designer

You will be walking with bags of excess food, which would have been thrown out by the restaurant, to the nearest homeless shelter. You will visit the store a few minutes before closing time, pick up the edible food in a plastic bag, and deliver the food to a local shelter.
10024.title: Assist in battling hunger

10024.description: From Monday to Sunday, Irving Farm in Irving Place will have edible produce that it is looking to donate. RoHo Compost is looking for a volunteer to help us transport this produce to a local shelter or food bank and people who are less fortunate. Someone with a car is preferred.
10024.title: Support the less fortunate by recovering food

10024.description: Volunteer as an EMT or non-medical provider with CPMU! http://www.cpmu.com/index.php/join-cpmu/
10024.title: Volunteer with the Central Park Medical Unit!

10024.description: Teens help alleviate loneliness and social isolation of DOROT's seniors through a variety of hands-on experiences in the community and onsite at DOROT. Apply here: http://www.dorotusa.org/site/PageServer?pagename=vol_school_year_internship#.WgyTp9QrLeM From a teen who visited a DOROT Senior: I LOVED THIS VISIT SO MUCH!!! It was really heartwarming and gratifying to see how elated Angie was after she opened the gifts that were in the birthday package. It was so nice to see someone so happy by our visit and what we brought with us. I felt very at ease and it was great talking to her and seeing her reaction to the gifts. -Jessica, 10th grade Teen Interns may: visit seniors in their home for companionship. teach seniors how to use a computer, iPad, iShuffle, and other types of technology. celebrate seniors’ birthdays. deliver meals to seniors. send birthday cards out to seniors. read to visually impaired seniors. shop and delivery groceries to seniors. play chess, cards, scrabble, and other games with seniors. assist with office work at DOROT. take part in a variety of other opportunities and experiences. Time Commitment: 1 day a week (Monday - Thursday) 2 hours a day (after school - no later than 4:00-6:00pm) 1 semester (minimum of 10 times at DOROT) Our Teen Internship has limited spots and is competitive, so teens must go through an application process. As a prospective intern, the first step is to fill out the interest form, then contact Shai Rosenfeld at 917-441-5051 for a brief phone interview. We take great care to find teen interns who are committed, responsible, reliable, and enthusiastic about working with seniors. Eligible teens are in 9th-12th grades.
10024.title: DOROT School Year TEEN Internship

10024.description: This opportunity is available every night! Excess bread can be combined with other ingredients to create meals to feed the hungry at a nearby food pantry rather than being thrown out. We will get bags of bread and walk for this fifteen minute event, and will finish at the Rectory at the Holy Trinity Catholic Church at 213 W 82nd Street. 10024.title: Fight Food Waste & Feed the Hungry in Upper West Side 8:05PM-8:20PM

Wednesdays & Thursdays, 10:30 AM - 12:00 PM 2017 Wednesday, November 1st Thursday, November 16th Wednesday, December 6th Thursday, December 21st 2018 Wednesday, January 3rd Thursday, January 18th DOROT will provide some supplies, bringing your own is preferred. Our DOROT seniors will benefit from your time and expertise. You will meet other volunteers and make new friends that share similar interests and are as passionate about volunteering as you. Volunteer Opportunities Inlcude: Cooking for Homelessness Prevention Program: SCHEDULED FOR 6/15/17 Speaking Exchange Video Chat Services Groups Intergenerational Programs Vist our website for more information: http://www.dorotusa.org/site/PageServer?pagename=vol_older_adult#.VkEWgLeFNdg

10024.title: Volunteer Tutors Needed!

10025.title: Serve Breakfast at St. Michael's Saturday Kitchen

10025.description: Whether you're great, good or fair at Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM), you can help make an impact on inner-city youth. Here's how: The Parris Foundation S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program has returned for the Fall 2017 session. The program began after a successful summer pilot in 2012, and our subsequent programs have grown to continue to serve middle school students and high school students . With the growing impact on the community, we need your support to continue to bring STEM to our middle school and high school youth throughout New York City. As we expand to more locations to serve more youth, there is a growing need for volunteers! How we do it: The Parris Foundation curriculum combines innovative and interactive software and teaching techniques with hand-ons interdisciplinary experiments and activities to keep our students engaged with their passion for science and math! About The Parris Foundation: The Parris Foundation is dedicated to promoting educational opportunities and fostering awareness in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) through scholarships and community outreach programs. The Parris Foundation's S.T.E.M.ulating Minds: Weekend Enrichment Programs provide extended learning opportunities to supplement and enhance in-school learning.
10025.title: Fall 2017 - S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program

10025.description: Top Honors is a non-profit educational organization that provides free math tutoring to NYC 5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th-graders. Tutoring takes place on Saturdays and Wednesday evenings at a school on the Upper West Side. New volunteer orientation and training sessions take place on a rolling basis. To receive an invitation, please submit an application here. Frequently asked questions about the TH volunteer experience can be found on our website. All tutoring sessions take place on the Upper West Side in Manhattan on the following days and times: Session 1: Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. Session 2: Saturdays from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. Session 3: Wednesdays from 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. Volunteers may be professionals, advanced high school, college, or graduate students (community service credit is available). Applicants should be available on Saturdays for two hours starting at 10 a.m. or 1:00 p.m. or on Wednesdays from 6:30 - 8 pm, like math, and enjoy working with students in the middle school age group (10-14 years). No prior experience is necessary. A note on volunteer commitment: Tutors attend 2-3 Saturdays from October and May, which includes holidays and school breaks. Attending 22 out of 27 scheduled sessions will meet this requirement. To apply, submit an online application at www.tophonors.org/volunteer. Upon receipt, Top Honors will contact the candidate directly.
10025.title: Do you love MATH? Volunteer MATH Tutors needed!

10025.description: Seeking a dynamic team of self-motivated individuals with exceptional leadership and organizing skills to assist in expanding our artistic and educational programs. Organization supports artists in art, literature and film communities. We're seeking volunteers in all areas to provide join our outstanding team of committed staff and volunteers. Areas of support: Graphic Design, social media promotion, fundraising, event and program management and non-profit capacity building experience. Must be willing to commit a minimum of 20 hours a month of service supporting our mission and goals. Please visit our websites and send your resume with a short cover letter to africanvoicesart@gmail.com.
10025.title: Dynamic Volunteers Needed for Arts Organization

10025.description: Would you like to make a difference with your dog? Disadvantaged children in New York City need help. Now you and your dog can help them. Become a volunteer team for A Fair Shake for Youth. A Fair Shake for Youth, Inc. is a non-profit that uses therapy dogs and AKC Canine Good Citizens to help middle-school aged youth in underserved communities build greater empathy and self-esteem, and reduce bullying. Dedicated volunteers and their dogs are at the heart of our program, power and success. Here's how it works: Three volunteer/dog teams each commit to a ten-week program Transportation is provided Teams work with the same group of 12 kids, becoming a consistent part of their school life Kids form a relationship with the volunteers and share the experience of making the dogs successful Volunteers experience a profound connection to the students - their struggles and success. Volunteers must be registered therapy dogs or AKC Canine Good Citizens.If your dog is not already one of these, training is available. We are looking for dogs that love people (especially children), are good with new situations, are resilient and well-mannered. For more information, please visit our website at www.afairshakeforyouth.org . If you and your dog would like to volunteer with us, please email volunteer@afairshakeforyouth.org
10025.title: Volunteer Dog Teams
10025.org: A Fair Shake for Youth, Inc.

10025.description: Walking Tour Guide Would you love to meet people from around the world? Do you love to show people around New York City? Everyday, we offer walking tours to see and experience New York City. This is the perfect opportunity to meet people from around the world. Daily Walking Tours meet at our beautiful Victorian mansion on the Upper West Side. From meeting location, we offer tours to Central Park, Brooklyn Bridge and all types of locations in the five boroughs of New York City. If you have a specific area of expertise whether it be a neighborhood, type of food, art, or anything else, you can propose a custom tour. Note: All volunteers must be punctual and able to commit to regular attendance over a 8-week term. Volunteers will: Give weekly or multi-weekly tours Foreign language ability is a plus but not a requirement Leaders can request tours for specific locations in the five boroughs Serve as representatives of New York to a global audience Help develop your public speaking and communication skills Receive volunteer hours that can be applied towards free hostel stays anywhere in our network of over 50 hostels in the USA Be eligible for volunteer trainings, appreciation events and more If you’re interested, please contact activities.newyork@hiusa.org for an application and more information. We’re looking for people who love to travel! HI New York is the largest nonprofit organization dedicated to youth travel in New York, and the largest hostel in North America.
10025.title: Walking Tour Guide

10025.description: Your work may be included in our upcoming, new website, presentations, videos, print, press releases and more for the End Poverty Campaign. IMPORTANT: For most activities, we require at least a year of experience - and several years for some activities. Except for those with high level, professional skills, we ask most volunteers to average at least 15 hours a week. Some exceptions to these guidelines are possible. You can speak with us about this before you come in. If possible, please include your resume, and we appreciate a link to samples of your work.
10025.title: GRAPHIC DESIGN: Branding, Print and/or Website

10025.description: Volunteer, Community Tax Aid Community Tax Aid, Inc. (CTA) is a nonprofit community service organization that provides free tax preparation for low-income individuals and families in New York City. We are the oldest free tax preparation service in the country. Extremely complex tax rules, the high price of accountants, and the fear of owing money make it both difficult and scary for low-income taxpayers to file their tax returns. At CTA, we offer training for our volunteers to guide these taxpayers through the filing process, and prepare and file the tax forms for them, all for free. We have locations in four boroughs: Brooklyn, Manhattan, The Bronx, and Queens. We offer CPE credits for qualifying CPAs and Volunteer certificates to those who request them. We are seeking responsible volunteers to assist our multiple locations from February through April. We provide necessary training, and have managers at each location review all tax returns. You can choose the volunteer location and days that are convenient for your schedule. We have opportunities during weekend days and weekday evenings. RESPONSIBILITIES INCLUDE: interviewing taxpayers data entry assembling returns SKILLS/QUALIFICATIONS: good written/oral communication previous tax experience is helpful but not required strong attention to detail second language skills a huge plus: Spanish, Haitian Creole, Mandarin, Cantonese, Korean, ASL positive, flexible, and friendly personality Contact: 646-200-5080, or email to ctaVolunteerInfo@aol.com (EMAIL preferred.) For additional information check out our website: www.communitytaxaidnyc.org
10025.title: Volunteer, Community Tax Aid NYC

10025.description: The New Jewish Home is seeking youth volunteers (13-17) who are available after school, weekends, and school breaks. As a youth volunteer, you will assist with Therapeutic Recreation and/or Religious Life programs. Programs include: BINGO, Arts & Crafts, Games, Religious Services, and Concerts. Youth volunteers can also provide one-on-one or small group interactions including:manicures, technology assistance (iPad, iPod & computers), card games, dominoes, checkers, chess, writing with or reading to an elder. 10025.description: Volunteering your time to change the lives of adults with developmental disabilities. Sprout is a non-profit organization based in New York City focused on providing innovative programs for adults with developmental disabilities.With our network of resources and dedicated volunteers, which we call leaders, Sprout opens up fascinating new worlds to people with disabilities. Sprout's Overnight Vacations Program is looking for individuals who have the energy, motivation and desire to work with adults with developmental disabilities. What do Sprout leaders do? Sprout leaders' primary goal is to give adults with developmental disabilities the opportunity to experience and enjoy recreational, educational and leisure activities through overnight vacations. Leaders are responsible for the overall safety and enjoyment of their group, 24 hours a day, while on a Sprout trip. Duties include safety monitoring, personal hygiene assistance, providing physical and emotional support, activity planning, budgeting, logistics, and enhancing fun. The work is hard yet immensely rewarding as you develop leadership skills and gain insight into your own abilities. What type of training is provided? Leaders must complete a pre-service training, which provides the necessary procedures and tools to run a successful and enjoyable vacation. Leaders who are drivers receive extra training on how to safely drive our 15-passenger vans. In addition, all leaders receive a copy of Sprout's Leadership Handbook to help with policies and guidelines. What is the time commitment? Sprout vacations last 3 - 7 days depending on the time of year and destination of the trip. When a leader is selected for an overnight vacation, Sprout asks that the leader dedicate themselves to stay with their group throughout the entire duration of the vacation. Some leaders only choose to lead one trip a year while others spend several months with us leading up to 8 trips or more. Sprout strives to make our program flexible for our leaders based on the amount of time leaders can give. Do leaders have any free or personal time while on a trip? Sprout trips are working vacations for the leaders who choose to participate. Because Sprout leaders are responsible for their group 24 hours a day, there is no free or personal time allotted. In order to give our participants the opportunity to experience and enjoy a vacation, Sprout leaders must be available at all times to provide the support any one participant may need. What type of trips can Sprout leaders expect to join? A majority of Sprout trips take place within a day's drive of New York City. Destinations include Atlantic City, Amish Country, Boston, Lake George, Cleveland, Maine and Virginia Beach. Exotic trips like cruises, Hawaii, and Europe are presented to leaders who have demonstrated high levels of commitment, service hours and have gained positive feedback from participants and Sprout office staff. Are there any special skills or requirements? No special background or education is required to become a Sprout leader. We encourage people from all cultures and professions, and of all ethnic and educational backgrounds. Once accepted into the program, you will receive the necessary tools to sign up for outings and how to assist our participants. Requirements include: -21+ years old -Provide references -Participate in training session -Willingness to complete necessary background checks -Evaluate participants' behavior -Fluent English -Willing to drive a 15 passenger van -Love to travel & have fun! How do I apply? TO APPLY: http://gosprout.org/vacation-programs/volunteer/volunteer-application/
10025.title: Vacation Trip Leader

10022.description: Cathedral High School (CHS) is a Catholic, college preparatory school located in the heart of Manhattan, which welcomes young women of all faiths and cultures. Since it opened its doors in 1905, Cathedral has been a place where young women feel at home and are encouraged to be strong, smart, independent women who can do anything they set their minds to. In 2012, Cathedral High School was ranked by The New York Observer as one of New York City’s top 160 schools and among the top 35 private high schools. Almost all of our students are daughters of immigrant working families. 645 young women representing 72 countries attend CHS. Many of our students come from families who earn at or below the federal poverty level (60% of students are eligible for free or reduced lunch). Over 82% of our girls are Hispanic or of African American descent. Through the decades, CHS has continued to enhance its academic curriculum and extra-curricular activities to ensure that students graduate equipped with the skills necessary to be successful in college and careers thereafter. CHS routinely graduates nearly 100% of its students - compared to a current graduation rate of 61.3% for NYC public schools - and assists students in securing tens of millions of dollars in college scholarships. CHS graduates have the skills to be competitive in the global workforce and a sense of obligation to others so that they give back to their New York City community. We are seeking Volunteer Board Members to help us fulfill this mission.

As the largest voluntary health organization in the country, we count on volunteers and volunteer driven organizations, agencies and companies to help make this event run smoothly and efficiently. 10023.description: Are you fascinated by architecture? New York City? History? Are you inspired to fight for the preservation of New York's architectural legacy? Are you looking for a way to learn more about these subjects, while helping in the fight to protect the physical history and human scale which give New York its unique and beloved character? If so, we're looking for your help. Landmark West! is a preservation watchdog and advocacy group that has been fighting for the protection of architecture on Manhattan's Upper West Side for over 30 years. We are currently working to catalog all the landmarks in our historic districts, and we are looking for some dedicated volunteers to help out with compiling our online database. The job entails reading designation reports and entering information on buildings listed, along with photographs and map coordinates, into an online template, and then adding the newly created entries to our public database. Requisites: Must be comfortable using basic online tools. Coding experience is not needed, but prior experience working with website builders such as WordPress would be helpful. Hours: Flexible, an afternoon a week, perhaps, at a time that works with your schedule. Our office hours are 9 AM to 6 PM, Monday through Friday.

10023.description: Music on the Inside, Inc. (MOTI) Connects incarcerated youth and at-risk youth with seasoned musicians to offer learning opportunities, creative encouragement and inspiring role models through the rehabilitative power of music. www.musicontheinside.org MOTI seeks two driven, inspired, and energetic individuals for a development Internship positions and an experienced office manager to help with day to day operations, systems, follow-up and correspondence. The Development Interns will work with MOTI’s Founder and team to support the organization’s fundraising efforts in identifying new funding prospects; prospect outreach; special events, including planning for MOTI’s Benefits; data research, tracking, and collection, etc. He/she will play an essential role in helping to bring MOTI’s advocacy, leadership, and membership efforts to the next level by assisting the organization in scoping out new funding opportunities. The ideal candidates have interest in fundraising, as well as advocacy and grassroots movement building, is a motivated, self-starter who is effective in a fast-paced environment, and possesses a great sense of humor. With our bold and ambitious goal and unique theory of change through music and mentorships for incarcerated and at-risk youth, this is an exciting professional opportunity. The right candidates can have a significant impact on redefining rehabilitation in corrections and justice in America. Requirements: * Candidates must demonstrate interest in incarceration reform, effective rehabilitation through music, addressing racial disparities in the criminal system, and a belief in the power and efficacy of music for encouraging leadership and social change. * Development Interns are expected to commit to a minimum of 20 hours per week for the duration of the internship, as well as remote working capabilities (as needed). Development Interns must be willing to be on site at correctional facilities, meetings and events to support all of MOTI’s advocacy, leadership, membership, and development/fundraising efforts as needed. * Excellent writing skills is a must as he/she will be assisting with drafting emails, proposals and other relevant communications distributed both internally and externally. These are unpaid internships but can be credit-bearing and Music on the Inside, Inc. will work with academic institutions to ensure credit approval, if applicable. Please submit with your interest in applying the following: Your interest in criminal justice reform and advocacy; Why you want to intern at Music on the Inside, Inc; The strengths and experience you bring to the team; Your time availability for a minimum of 2-3 days; And what you are looking to experience? Only applicants selected for interviews will be contacted. Music on the Inside, Inc. (www.musicontheinside, inc.) is an equal opportunity/affirmative action employer. All qualified applicants will be considered for employment without unlawful discrimination based on race, color, creed, national origin, sex, age, disability, marital status, sexual orientation, military status, prior record of arrest or conviction, citizenship status, or curretn employment status. Music on the Inside values diverse experiences, including with regard to the justice system.
10023.title: Development and Administrative assistance for Music on the Inside, Inc.

10023.description: Your unique collection of life experiences can make a tremendous impact on the lives of young people new to America. By volunteering as a mentor with Table Wisdom you will have the chance to cultivate invaluable relationships as a mentor while helping foreign born students and young professionals practice their conversational English skills. It's as easy as signing up, getting paired, and starting a conversation. You and your mentee set the schedule and the student is expected to prepare topics for conversation. Our pairs talk about everything: from sports and culture to industry-specific skills and knowledge, what you discuss is up to you and your mentee. We do our best to pair people in similar disciplines so our mentees can learn from your career-specific experience, and you can learn more about what's new in your field. By having fun yet meaningful conversations you will help students build their confidence and fluency in English. All you need is the ability to video chat and the desire to meet someone new. Help a young foreign born person improve their quality of life in America. Join Table Wisdom: https://www.table-wisdom.org/join-us \"Although our lives are so different and perhaps distant, it is encouraging that there is so much that we share trying to be our best selves and making this a better world.\" -- Alan, mentor \"I feel so blessed to have met my excellent English language mentor. He always encourages me to speak out and taught me some idiomatic English which I didn't learn from a textbook.\" -- Zachary, mentee
10023.title: Share your experience! Mentor foreign born students and young professionals

10021.description: We are seeking early evening and overnight hosts for our homeless shelter. We are particularly interested in overnight hosts. Our shelter runs every week of the year, from Sunday-Thursday. The early evening host (6:30pm-8:30pm): Welcomes and checks-in the guests. Prepares the breakfast tray. Offers a light snack for those who missed dinner at the Drop-in Center. Makes sure that everyone has enough linens, blankets, and toiletries to be comfortable and cleans up the table and kitchen. The overnight host (8:30pm-7:00am): Organizes food clean-up with help from the guests. Makes sure breakfast is ready to go. Ensures the smooth operation of the shelter overnight, from 10:00pm lights-out to wake up, breakfast and departure in the morning. Leaves the kitchen and guest area clean and neat. Early and Overnight Hosts can volunteer by themselves or with a friend/partner/family member/etc. Our volunteers are committed to serving our shelter guests. Most hosts serve at least twice/month. Prospective hosts must attend an Open House orientation or contact us to arrange for an individual orientation. Open House Orientations are held on a monthly basis at 1:00 p.m., meeting at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. We rely on our volunteer hosts to keep the shelter open, so we need dependable volunteers to show up for and complete every shift they agree to fill. Volunteers must be 18 or older. Volunteers must also be able to lift 20 lbs for snack set-up.

10010.description: Crisis Text Line provides free, nationwide, 24/7 support for people in crisis, all via text message. The service is powered by volunteer Crisis Counselors who work remotely anywhere with a computer and secure internet connection. Crisis Counselors answer texts from people in crisis, bringing them from a hot moment to a cool calm through active listening, collaborative problem solving, and safety planning. Apply to volunteer at crisistextline.org/volunteer HOW DO YOU BECOME A CRISIS COUNSELOR? Step 1: Fill out the 30-minute application at crisistextline.org/volunteer Step 2: Consent to a background check Step 3: Complete the 34-hour web-based training Step 4: Take your first shift and start changing lives! You will commit to volunteering 200 total hours, at your own pace. Shifts are two hours long. THE PERKS Learn skills. In 34 hours, you’ll walk away knowing active listening, collaborative problem solving, and crisis management. (These are skills that will help in your personal relationships too!) Train & volunteer from the comfort of your home. Oooh, impressive! Our Crisis Counselors highlight the training on their resumes when interviewing for jobs, applying to grad school, and building out their LinkedIn profile. VOLUNTEER WORK THAT ENRICHES YOUR LIFE Level up. Earn volunteer leadership positions. Get the first crack at Crisis Text Line internships and job openings. Gain access to special privileges, including discounts and swag. Hone your skills. Work alongside volunteers who are also social workers, therapists, and psychiatrists to sharpen your crisis counseling skills-while in your jammies, at home! Feel supported. This is a community. We support each other. We are a big awesome family. READY TO VOLUNTEER? APPLY HERE: crisistextline.org/volunteer Questions? Email: support@crisistextline.org
10010.title: Save lives from your couch by becoming a Crisis Counselor
